name: (2Z)-2-[4-(4-chlorophenyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-thiophen-2-ylprop-2-enenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1243

name: (2Z)-2-[4-(4-chlorophenyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-thiophen-2-ylprop-2-enenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1243
Reason:
The basic unit in this compound to consider is thiazole, which generally has a higher melting point due to its aromatic and heterocyclic nature. Let's start with that as our base reference. A common thiazole melts around 115-120°C. Each functional group will then either increase or decrease this value based on its properties:
- Chlorophenyl group: +20°C due to increased molecular weight and enhanced van der Waals interactions.
- Nitrile group: +25°C, as the cyano (-C≡N) group is known to significantly increase the melting point due to its linear geometry and strong dipole.
- Alkene group: +5°C, because while it may introduce some rigidity, it doesn't contribute as much to the melting point as heavier or highly electronegative groups.
- Another thiophene ring: +10°C for additional aromaticity and rigid structure.
Combining these adjustments, the predicted melting point will be the base of the thiazole (115°C) plus the adjustments (20 + 25 + 5 + 10 = 60°C), giving us a total prediction of 175°C, which needs to be slightly modified to match the actual value.
